text: NFL Betting 2020: Player props for the NFL's Week 2 Sunday slate.
Player props are one of the easiest transitions for fantasy enthusiasts to get involved in sports betting, and the Week 2 Sunday slate offers some enticing under options.
Published by Ben Brown on Sunday, September 20th, 2020.

Utilizing our player props tool has been beneficial to sports bettors' bankrolls to start the 2020 season, as the ability to adjust both number and price means you are always certain of the expected value for each prop bet.

Written picks have also done well, going 14-7 as we head into the main Sunday slate of Week 2. This record is based on grading against the closing-line number; we have profited six units when minus-priced props are set to win one unit and plus-money props risk one unit.

This slate is going to be defined by its high totals. The mean total among all games for Week 2 of the 2020 season is the 13th-highest of any regular season week over the past 10 seasons. This information provides context for how we should approach what the betting market believes should be a high-scoring week.

Just because game totals go over doesn't mean player props always follow suit. There is typically concentrated production from a few high-end players who smash the over on their player props but leave little room for the rest of their teammates to do the same. Let's dive into the best player props to make as we head into the main slate of Week 2. If you would like to hear a full discussion of all player props for this Sunday's slate, make sure to listen to the PFF Daily Betting podcast.
Davante Adams over 7.5 receptions.

I am now contractually obligated to mention at least one over in this column, and there is no better option than Green Bay Packers wide receiver Davante Adams, who saw over 40% of his team's target percentage in Week 1.

Adams also had the highest rate of targets based on routes run among all wide receivers. This prop number is the same as it was in Week 1, with slightly less juice applied to the over. The betting market is anchored to player-prop numbers on a weekly basis, with little adjustment occurring from week to week outside of a change in scenario or scheme. Adams' reception total sat at 6 or 6.5 for all but one week in 2019. This resulted in an offseason adjustment after the under cashed three times.

The Detroit Lions' secondary is going to be depleted again in Week 2; Desmond Trufant has already been ruled out, so the expectation is that Amani Oruwariye lines up against Adams for the majority of pass routes. Jeff Okudah is also expected to make his NFL debut but could be in for a rude awakening to the NFL if he is expected to shadow Adams.

The total has moved up 4 points since the open, with 92% of the cash and 88% of the tickets on the over. Despite Week 1 performances, the spread has moved in the direction of Detroit. If the Lions can keep this game relatively close, then Adams should have no issues hitting the over on 7.5 receptions as he continues to show that he is the focal point of this Packers offense.
DeAndre Hopkins over 6.5 receptions.
I am doubling down with overs on two players who could easily lead the NFL in targets this season. The only receiver with a higher team target share than Davante Adams in Week 1 was Hopkins.

Things look promising for Hopkins in Arizona. He caught 14 of his 16 targets against the second-highest-graded coverage unit in the 2019 regular season. The betting market has adjusted to this change in scenery — after printing a Week 1 number of 5.5 receptions, the market has moved back to the mean of Hopkins' reception props from 2019. This still might be too low since the Cardinals had the second-most offensive snaps in Week 1 along with the third-highest number of pass plays. The spread offense should see a higher distribution of targets to ulterior receivers, but most see this as a detriment to Hopkins' volume without adjusting for the increase in opportunities given the fast pace of the Cardinals offense.

If the Washington Football Team plays to the level it did in Week 1, then the blowout risk is low for this matchup in Arizona. Arizona should continue their 65% pass-to-run ratio as long as things stay close this weekend. This would provide plenty of opportunities for Hopkins to obliterate his reception total for the second straight week.
Tyler Higbee under 4.5 receptions.

Higbee was an afterthought in the Los Angeles Rams' offense in Week 1. He ran a pass route on 65% of Jared Goff's dropbacks and was targeted four times. His reception prop number dropped half a point from Week 1, but it still seems inflated, given the expectation that Gerald Everett is able to play today.

This offense seems focused on getting Robert Woods the ball in space, as his six targets had a combined 16 air yards. Van Jefferson appears more than capable of being the deep threat as the third receiver in this offense, too. Cooper Kupp is also going to get more opportunities than he did in Week 1, which leaves Higbee as the odd man out in games that aren't expected to have a positive game script.

The betting market has moved heavily away from the idea of a shootout in Philadelphia, with the total dropping 3.5 points since the open. If this holds true, there simply aren't enough targets available to Higbee to get him close to this reception total. It is a prime spot to take the under before the market corrects to where it realistically should be.
Christian McCaffrey under 5.5 receptions.

This is a situation where the market hasn't fully adjusted to the offseason change in philosophy for the Panthers. Joe Brady's style of offense isn't highlighting targets to running backs in space anywhere close to the volume that McCaffrey has seen previously. McCaffrey's reception total has seen a big change to his Week 1 number but is still slightly anchored to a previous regime's offensive philosophy.

The game script for Carolina in Week 1 was a perfect situation for McCaffrey to see targets. This simply didn't transpire, however, so the expectation that things change in a similar game script setup for Week 2 is an oversight. McCaffrey will be heavily involved in this offense, but with three legitimate receivers on the outside, the target split by position that we saw in Week 1 will continue going forward.
